;Suzuki Ryomi’s mother is Haijima Kari, a researcher of Japanese children’s literature. , she wrote a collection of essays "A Bouquet for Love and the Womb" before and after taking care of her sick mother, unfolding this complex mother-daughter relationship that is both alienated and full of love. ;(Visual China/Picture);

;

;Suzuki Ryomi is a "hot girl who grew up in Tokyo", who is in love with Cinderella-style misfortune. Will consider themselves a victim. Her speeches and works reveal lightness, some humor, and inherent heaviness and pain.

;

;In the collection of essays "A Bouquet for Love and the Womb", she devoted a lot of space to writing about her rebellion against her original family. Her family must be the envy of most people. Her mother is the translator Kari Haijima, and her father is Suzuki Akira, an honorary professor at Hosei University. Happiness is hard-won, and the pieces of life gradually accumulate tension between mother and daughter.

;

;“We are not free. Although we are not expecting a big reversal of fortune, we are still shackles. We can always feel the mother’s curse hidden between our spine and skin, and we can’t help but feel chills in our bones. ." The book writes about the mother's overly ardent hopes for her daughter. She wanted to get rid of the regrets she had in her original family and married life, but she changed her mind and injected specific trivialities into her daughter's life, always in the name of love.

;

;If she follows the established path, Suzuki Ryomi can easily become the stereotype of a "decent person". That was not the case. She knew a part of the world that many people knew and experienced, but few could express. After entering the night world by mistake, she discovered many familiar stories among the women around her.

;

;"As long as you walk into the night, you will temporarily forget everything else. The longer you sink into the dazzling and crazy world, and the longer you stay in a world that worships emptiness as nobility, the less you can touch it. That thing." Suzuki Ryomi sold underwear to middle-aged men in high school. After graduation, she "couldn't wait to go to nightclubs and work many odd jobs."

;

;The nightlife compared to the daytime is indeed paradoxical, "there are as many girls as Cinderella-like as you want." Women pay for the cowherd, who is often more domineering; female escorts need to endure the domineering male guests. A large number of details more or less reflect the essence of gender issues.

;

;The men and women there occasionally share the cruel joys and sorrows. As time goes by, the fragile "equality" will inevitably disappear, and the people in the night world have overdrawn their youth early. Many female practitioners in custom shops have decent family backgrounds and education, and college students often work part-time jobs at night; while the cowherds are often in a difficult situation, with average education levels and lack of ability to make a living. All these people will age.

;

;Suzuki Ryomi went to graduate school and wrote a master's thesis on pornographic film actresses. She worked as a journalist and later resigned. In 2014, "Weekly Bunshun" reported on her past as an actress in pornographic films. She is now a well-known author and considered a sociologist, although she denies the latter.

;

;When she started writing "Flowers for Love and the Womb," her mother had her first cancer surgery. Some time later, my mother's cancer recurred, and she died half a year before finishing the book. Her mother repeatedly said: "I'm sorry, I still have many things to tell you, but I don't have time." Through writing and recalling, Suzuki Ryomi discovered the similarities between herself and her mother, and also understood more about her mother's various ways of doing things. . She once said: "It is very lonely to lose such an enemy and a friend."

;

;Later than "Flowers for Love and the Womb", Suzuki Ryomi's correspondence with the scholar Chizuru Ueno The collection "Starting from the Limit" was published. She was born in 1983, more than thirty years younger than Chizuru Ueno. The age gap between the two is about the same as that of mother and daughter. It is no surprise that there is a huge difference in the perspective of understanding the world. In the correspondence, she mentioned that a man who had had sexual relations several times said to his friend in a serious manner in front of her: "Which man is willing to date a woman who has acted in AV." Those men who bought underwear had already The impression that it was impossible for me to understand this creature seemed to be happening again.

;

;Suzuki Ryomi's mother always said: "If you are caught for fraud or terrorist activities, I will do my best to stand with you. If you become an AV actress, forget it." "Such words are like the swan song that Ms. Haijima Kari sang for part of her life. At the same time, she also said: "I am very happy. I have raised a good daughter."

;

;;

;

;UTF-8'' Japanese writer Suzuki Ryomi was born in an intellectual family in Tokyo in 1983. She once worked as a bartender and a pornographic film actress. After retiring, she was admitted to the University of Tokyo for a master's degree and became a journalist. He was shortlisted for the Akutagawa Prize, Japan's highest literary award, for two years. He is well-known to Chinese readers for his collection of dialogues with Chizuru Ueno, "Starting at the Limit." ;(Photo courtesy of the publisher);

;

;;"At least my mother is not the kind of person who doesn't care about the world";

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;There is an impressive description of mother in the book: "They are performing another kind of mysterious and unspeakable magic, never stopping, spreading the powder called love to us." You then recorded some suffocating past events. So, can you go back to that statement? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;The relationship with the mother has an immeasurable impact on the child's future life. This is not a simple dichotomy of love and dislike, likes and dislikes, respect and contempt, but a complex interaction between the mother's expectations, preferences, personality and habits and the child's personality and life. Although there are exceptions, it is generally believed that mothers love their children, and I can indeed feel that my mother loves me. However, I feel that the so-called "love" is not always warm and soft, there is also a lot of mud and roughness in it. Many young people will more or less rebel against their parents' overbearing and overly strong love and achieve independence by having a world unknown to their mothers. But even so, the relationship and influence with the mother is more or less undeniable. I use the word "magic" to describe this feeling: I had been a part of my mother's life, and once I became independent, I would be separated from her, but never completely separated, as if by magic. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;After several years, your feelings for your mother have changed. What changes? Has the “magic” faded? Will you understand her better because of some memories? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;Basically, I think as we grow older, we will slowly have our own world that our parents don’t know about. The "magic" with our mother fades because we will have faces that we can share with others but have never shown our parents, and things we have never told them. During my bad teenage years, I managed to develop a relationship with my parents: I was connected to them but didn't necessarily share everything with them. It is not so much that a certain memory has deepened my understanding of my mother, but that now that my mother has passed away and time has passed, when I am the same age as the mother who once raised me, I recall every bit of our childhood. I sometimes imagine that maybe that was the mood. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You are in "A Bouquet for Love and the Womb" "" writes about the subtle emotions between mother and daughter. They both think that the other is in a better position, which seems to be a kind of competition between mother and daughter. Is this phenomenon common between mothers and daughters? Or is it unique to your family? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;Mother and daughter are the two closest and most similar people in the world. Dependent on mother's relationship. When they grow up, they are in an environment where they can conform to the same gender, and naturally a very complex and primitive competitive relationship will arise. I think many people have had this experience. During adolescence, they are unwilling to accept the female side of their mother, but sometimes mothers are also unwilling to accept the female side of their daughters. I think there is a subtle psychology in it. Both of them obviously love each other very much, but they don't want her to be like themselves. I think the meaning of parents in life is different for everyone, and for me, they are the ones who keep asking me questions. Even now that they have passed away, I feel like I am still being questioned by my mother. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;In China, parents often want their children to have a partner. , or urging marriage due to family reproduction issues. Is this phenomenon common in Japan? If so, does it have anything to do with the gender of the child? Is the reason due to child care issues, or is it just a stubborn point of view? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;In recent years, it is said that more and more parents value their children's wishes or feel lonely when their children finally get married. But I often heard in the past that if you are still single at the age of thirty, your parents will nag you to get married. This situation still exists in some areas of Japan and elsewhere. Marriage in Japan used to be a family affair. Marriage is a necessary means to maintain the survival of the family, so the pressure on the eldest son is particularly great. Women, for their part, want to marry themselves off, even though it has nothing to do with the survival of their own families. But Japan is a country with a lot of peer pressure. Everyone else gets married at about this age. Only my family doesn’t get married. People will talk about it. ;

;

;However, I have recently begun to think that in real life, there may be a more real desire, and that is the happiness of children. Of course, there are forms of single happiness. But I think parents still hope that their daughters can experience the happiness of starting a family, and do not want their daughters to live alone in this world one day after they die. At least my mother is not the kind of person who doesn't care about the world, so when she said she hoped I could have a companion one day, I felt she was doing it for my own good and hoped I could experience the happiness she experienced. Of course, some people may feel stressed or nosy about this. And in Japan, some sexual orientations are not recognized and can be married, so I can't say that this is completely well-intentioned.

;

;Finally, I think it's best not to take your parents' words too seriously, just listen to their opinions from time to time, but don't take them too seriously.

;

;;"Now that I am really 40 years old, ;;but ;;not much has changed";

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;As expressed in the Chinese word "forty without confusion", it seems that people of this age will understand There are many principles, such as how to treat others and how to fight for rights and interests. You mentioned in "Flowers for Love and the Womb" that when you were about thirty years old, you discovered that the few people who stayed in Tokyo were not only friends, but also survivors. When you were forty, did you have a similar realization? A certain idea that seems natural actually changes quietly with age. ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;When I was a teenager or 20 years old, I imagined that I would know clearly when I was 40 years old. No matter what you want to do or what you don’t want to do, your relationship with others will be stable. But now that I'm actually forty, I feel like I haven't changed much. I still wanted a lot of things, still lacked confidence in myself, and still worried about what others thought of me. I didn’t grow much. At least work-wise, though, I have more experience than I had in my twenties, so I have more concrete ideas about what I want to do in the future. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;So, when communicating with younger girls , do you feel the generational difference obviously? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;Sometimes I feel there is no difference, and sometimes I feel it is completely different. Overall, young girls today are much more docile, kind, classy and mature than they were when we were young. But at the same time, they don’t have that much energy to do stupid things when they are young. Perhaps it is because Japan's economy has been in recession for a long time and people are full of uncertainty about the future. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You said in "Starting from the Limit", "Standing at the limit, I look at things from where I am." Are there any recent changes or shifts in the “limits” of how you view the world? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;I may be a pessimist, a realist at best, a cynic at worst, so I had a habit from the beginning of limiting my expectations, assuming that things were never going to change no matter what. Society won't change anyway, so let's enjoy freedom as much as possible in this society, etc. However, for example, the issue of sexual assault has recently begun to be widely reported in Japan, which was unimaginable twenty years ago. In this sense, I think I should be more idealistic. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Are you because of communicating with Ms. Chiheko No? , and lead to some new thinking? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;I don’t think I have changed drastically since we ended the correspondence. It's just that when I think about something, I ask myself, "Is this really the case?" "Isn't there anyone else who has such an idea?" I think the main thing is that now I have another channel to think about problems. ;

;

;;When a woman has several categories of attributes;;, ;;it often scares men;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;What literature and social science books have had a great influence on you? ;

;

;;Ryomi Suzuki:;;For example, Mieko Kanai's "Yeye Shengge" and Inoue Yasu's "Japanese Grammar". When I was young, I didn't really realize that thinking about problems was an exciting thing. I thought it was more exciting to give up thinking, such as nightlife and consumption. But after encountering a good book, I realized that the opposite was actually true. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;What does the night world currently occupy in your life? What proportion? Would you talk about your identity as a writer and sociologist with your friends in the night world? Do they understand this part of your life? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;In the current life, the participation rate in the night world is now almost 0%, up to 10%, but my brain I still spend 50% of my time thinking about the people living in the night world. I don’t consider myself a sociologist, but not many of my former Night World friends know that I’m a writer. Whether it is current acquaintances or new friends, everyone knows that I also write books. In fact, I don’t think it’s unusual for someone with a nightlife background to write a book. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Will the temporary equality of the sexes in the night world be possible? Will it become more and more unstable as we age? For example, if an elderly cowherd no longer engages in this job, he may become a grumpy uncle. Will the equality brought about by sharing the joys and sorrows with the women around him easily disappear? ;

;

;;Ryomi Suzuki:;;York World is basically divided into male and female characters, and I feel like gender equality is not well recognized there. Because many people sell their looks, youth has great commercial value, and this trend is more obvious among women. Rather, this "world" in the sense that young women here have more power than middle-aged men can create a different gender balance than the normal daylight world. Yet it is also a sad world, as young capital is dwindling every year. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Read "A Bouquet for Love and the Womb" When reading, I feel through words that men and women in the night world are somewhat insecure. What kind of protection should they get? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;Even those who once had no problem surviving in the night world will later encounter problems in life due to the loss of youth. difficulty. I think there should be social security for people who have problems after leaving the night world. Indeed, some people enter the night world at an early age and have no choice. The best social security is to give them the opportunity to receive a proper education, regardless of the circumstances of their birth. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Can you imagine an ideal relationship between the sexes? Way? What is your understanding of the “male gaze”? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;I still don’t know what an ideal relationship should be like, where we use each other’s fantasies without hurting each other. Change slowly and flexibly? When you want to use one word to describe the male gaze, you can actually imagine a lot of things. For example, when dividing the roles that women play for men into different categories, I think it is masculine: mother, wife, coworker, mistress , prostitutes, students, etc. When a woman has several attributes at the same time, many people will be very angry. For example, when a colleague is a mistress or his wife is a prostitute, it often scares men. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Finally, could you introduce your current work progress? ? For example, your novel "Backstroke" tells the story of a forty-year-old woman looking back on her life. Is this a summary for you? ;

;

;;Suzuki Ryomi:;;In "Backstroke", I only reviewed what happened in a certain month when I was nineteen, so I can't say It is completely autobiographical, but it reflects strongly on my experiences. When I turned thirty-nine, I realized that twenty years had passed. When writing a novel, I often draw from past experiences or memories and weave them into a text. This is nothing special. But I have a soft spot for it because it is closer to my own experience than anything else I have ever written. ;

;On February 22, 2018, men's short track speed skating at the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics in South Korea In the 500-meter final, Wu Dajing won the championship ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;;The "new journey" of the speed skating veteran;

;

;On a windy winter day in Beijing, Wu Dajing appeared in the studio to record an exclusive interview.

;

;The shooting plane required a change of thin clothes. In order to relax him and quickly complete the shooting, the photographer joked: "It is summer at 30℃!" Wu Dajing showed a big boy's smile and cooperated patiently.

;

;This day is November 12, 2023. What a coincidence is that on November 12, 2018, five years ago, Wu Dajing won the Men’s Short Track Speed ​​Skating World Cup Salt Lake City Station in the 2018-2019 season. In the 500-meter final, he won the championship with a time of 39.505 seconds, breaking his own world record set at the PyeongChang Winter Olympics in February 2018. As of now, Wu Dajing is still the holder of both the Olympic record and the world record in this event.

;

;In the past five years, Wu Dajing has experienced the glory brought by his fame-at his peak in 2018, he broke the world record three times in a year and set a new Olympic record; he has also experienced the trough-injury. Under heavy pressure, he finally stood on the highest podium at the Beijing Winter Olympics.

;

;After the Beijing Winter Olympics, for 28-year-old Wu Dajing, it was the best time to retire after success. Age and injuries will only bring greater uncertainty to the future. Retiring at this time can be regarded as a perfect ending. But Wu Dajing chose to continue standing on the ice rink.

;

;"Recently, I have been carrying out rehabilitation and restorative training step by step." Wu Dajing said. In 2023, he participated in some domestic competitions and will continue to participate in other competitions next year and beyond. What he is most worried about is the recurrence of old injuries, like an elusive bomb. He doesn’t know when it will explode next. “So now I try to extend my cycle as much as possible and make a sufficient long-term plan. It must be very scientific. Be careful and you may not make it to the end if you are not careful at all."

;

;;

;

;Wu Dajing feels relaxed

;

;He has been preparing for the Beijing Winter Olympics for 4 years. Before the game, he injured his right knee, and then the waist injury recurred. "It was a particularly hard blow at that time, because you didn't know if you could play. All the athletes had gone to train, and I was the only one lying there. It was quite uncomfortable. One thing, I was very helpless. At that time, I felt like a child, knowing nothing and unable to do anything."

;

;In the end, he withstood the pressure, worked with the team, and won the short track speed He won a gold medal in the men's and women's 2000-meter mixed skating relay, which was also China's first gold medal at the Beijing Winter Olympics. After the game, he and Fan Kexin hugged each other tightly. As the oldest athletes in the men's and women's teams, they have both experienced three Olympic Games. "At that moment, we really understood each other with just one look. It was like watching a movie in my mind, and all the details of the preparations for the war in the past few years emerged." Wu Dajing recalled.

;

;Many people once said to him, "Otherwise you will quit."

;

;"There will also be entanglements. At some point, I feel that otherwise I will quit. Because no matter from the perspective of Neither my physical condition nor my age condition is in the best state, so I weighed and compared myself, but in the end I still felt that I couldn’t let it go. Skating has always been my passion. As an athlete, I have been engaged in my favorite industry for so many years. It doesn't mean that you can just let it go. For me now, it's easy to persist, but it's not easy to let go." Wu Dajing said.

;

;Wu Dajing has created many histories of short track speed skating in China and is called the "King of Sprints" by the International Skating Union. He is the first Chinese men's Olympic gold medal in ice racing and the first Chinese men's Olympic gold medal in short track speed skating. At the PyeongChang Winter Olympics, he won the championship with a time of 39.584 seconds, breaking the world record and Olympic record, and won the first and only gold medal for the Chinese team at the Winter Olympics.

;

;From being a sparring partner for the women's team to becoming a world champion, he described it as "every time he is breaking through and challenging himself." Now, facing this new journey, what he needs to challenge is his mentality, which is different from the past. "Enjoy the process of preparing for the war, the process of training and sweating every day, and the process of tiring myself to exhaustion every day. The rest is Yes, results are no longer the only important thing to me. The moment athletes are on the court, they actually have to prove that they have achieved good results, but now I am more passionate about it, so I use a better mentality to do it. Prepare, maybe it will be better. I can still be an athlete, I can still stand on the ice rink, I think this is enough."

;

;;

;

;Wu Dajing's sense of relaxation< /p>;

;;Childhood;;, ;;Training Ground and New Identity;

;

;In August 2023, Wu Dajing became A coach in the short track speed skating project of Jilin Provincial Sports Bureau Ice Sports Management Center. As both an athlete and a coach, this is a new beginning.

;

;In fact, before Wu Dajing became a coach, he began to play the role of a link in the team very early. In September 2018, Wu Dajing was elected as the new captain of the Chinese short track speed skating team. In addition to improving his own skills, he also began to cultivate the team's ability to collaborate with each other.

;

;This reminded him of his childhood, when young athletes were afraid of their coaches. When Wu Dajing first joined the national team, because the coach's energy was limited, he would give more time to the main athletes. "So when I was in my first and second year with the national team, I felt very happy if the coach could say a word to me one day and help me with a move. The coach talked to me, and I was happy all day long. "When he didn't talk to me or give me guidance, it was a very uncomfortable day." Wu Dajing recalled.

;

;“At this time, we need someone in the team who is both a senior and a teammate to stand up and tell us the most real physical condition or problems we encounter, and then we will help. He changes or helps him avoid some detours. We have been doing this in recent years." Wu Dajing pointed out that the coach's attention may affect the mentality of the players, and he hopes that he can play such a role - - Help coaches share attention, help juniors, and become a bond between them.

;

;;

;

;Wu Dajing feels relaxed

;

;From personal responsibility to collective glory, Wu Dajing fully feels the strength and value brought by a team. "Skating left me with beautiful and scary experiences in my childhood. From the collective life I experienced as a child, to the relationship I had with my teammates when I grew up, to the time I was able to represent my motherland in competitions and perform on the world stage. Himself. This experience is wonderful and worth remembering."

;

;In his childhood, he usually had to get up at more than 4 o'clock in the morning. The winter in the Northeast is extremely cold. There are no street lights in small cities. His mother rides a bicycle to take him to the ice rink, and the road is covered with snow. Before dawn, they put up a light on the ice rink. "We were training there, and parents used big brooms to sweep the ice on the ice rink. There was a clear division of labor - there were those who swept the ice and those who poured the ice. Then these parents I spontaneously built a simple shed and lit a fire inside to keep warm." There is no board wall outside such a training place, and parents use snow to build a protective wall to prevent the children from falling out.

;

;When I was a child, because the price of skates was relatively expensive, I usually bought larger ones. My feet hurt, and they often bleed and scab over and over again. "But when I was a child, I didn't feel bitter. (I even) felt that it was very comfortable on the ice rink, and I could even put on skates. I didn't feel cold at that time, but now I think about it, it is really cold. I am particularly afraid of the cold now. Maybe when I was a child It’s too cold.” Wu Dajing smiled.

;

;Wu Dajing once said that he has a pair of "very ugly feet". He has accumulated "pimples" due to ill-fitting skates and accumulated training over the years, and even has deformed bones in some places. "I said that I must wear good shoes and buy good shoes in the future. The thing I am most sorry for in my life is my feet. They have been witnessing my journey of more than ten years. From the beginning of skating to now, I still feel He is still accompanying me through hardships. He often jokes that I will take better care of my feet in the future."

;

;In 2019, Wu Dajing built a charity ice rink in his hometown of Jiamusi, Heilongjiang to support his hometown. The short track career is located at the "wild ice rink" where he trained when he was a child. He hopes to give his children more training venues.

;

;Nowadays, this public ice rink has a lot of people in winter, including children and ice skating enthusiasts, and they organize themselves to maintain the ice rink. "I don't think I built it in vain. Many people use it. Children, the elderly, and young people can all skate here. I think it is a very meaningful thing and can help more people."

;

;Wu Dajing also feels happy to devote himself to public welfare undertakings. After he won his first gold medal at the Beijing Winter Olympics, he got a golden dungeon and would sleep with it in his arms. But on the closing day, he decided to auction off the Golden Dundun and donate the proceeds to the "Project Hope·Dajing Ice and Snow Charity Project" to create conditions for ice and snow sports for rural teenagers. He feels, "We can help others with visible results, which maximizes its meaning."

;

;;

;

;February 5, 2022, in Beijing in the winter of 2022 In the mixed team relay final of the Olympic short track speed skating event, the Chinese team won the championship. Wu Dajing celebrates after the game ;(Xinhua News Agency/Photo);

;

;;“;;As long as you feel worthy It is enough for you to be worthy of the;;project you are engaged in;;”;

;

;;Southern People Weekly ：;;As a veteran of short track speed skating, what kind of new stage of life do you think you have entered? ;

;

;;Wu Dajing:;;Now there is an additional coach to help the team improve together. This is a new beginning, and it is enough to continue to shine in this project. Although I am in a confused period now and I feel like I still want to prove myself, my mentality will have changed a bit compared to before, but I can still stand on the training ground and exert all my strength, which is enough. . ;

;

;Competitive sports not only test results, but also test mentality. In the past, you just had to practice well by yourself, but now it is different. You need to think about the entire team and the young athletes, and the responsibilities on your shoulders are heavier.

;

;We can no longer joke with our teammates as unscrupulously as before. This team needs to move forward. I am also slowly exploring this process, not only integrating into the feelings between our athletes and teammates, but also improving my identity as a coach.

;

;;Southern People Weekly:;;If you use three keywords to describe yourself, what would you do? Which three to choose? ;

;

;;Wu Dajing:;;Luck, happiness, and expectation. ;

;

;I was lucky because I had a wonderful childhood, did things that other children did not challenge, and achieved ideal results. When we are athletes, we have a strong motherland to support us. We are lucky to have such a glorious moment.

;

;Happiness is that I can still do what I like to do now, and maybe in a few years, I can still engage in this career. This is the happiness of the moment.

;

;The expectation is that I will face the choice of transformation in the future. Whether I am an athlete, a coach, or engaged in other things in the industry, it will be a new test for me. I am looking forward to the arrival of a new life, especially yearning for it.

;
